docs.lead_paragraph: The Onion describes itself as ''America's finest news source,'' and it's not an idle boast. On Jan. 18, 2001, the satirical weekly bore the headline ''Bush: Our long national nightmare of peace and prosperity is finally over,'' followed by this mock quotation: ''We must squander our nation's hard-won budget surplus on tax breaks for the wealthiest 15 percent. And, on the foreign front, we must find an enemy and defeat it.'' Whatever our qualms about how we got here, all Americans now hope that the foreign front proceeds according to plan. Meanwhile, let's talk about the fiscal front.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column, citing projections of Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, says long-term finances of United States government are in much worse shape than Bush administration has admitted, and it is Bush's tax cuts, not deficits of Social Security and Medicare, that are to blame

docs.lead_paragraph: Barely a year after taking office on a pledge to restore the Mount Sinai Medical Center to economic health, its chief executive, Dr. Kenneth I. Berns, is leaving his post, and up to 500 health care workers will be laid off in a hospitalwide shake-up, administrators said yesterday. The job cuts, which will take effect within the next few weeks, come on top of the loss of about 430 positions already cut over the last year, as the hospital -- long one of the nation's premier teaching hospitals and an imposing presence on Manhattan's Upper East Side -- has struggled with problems in its finances, its administration and its medical reputation.

headline.main: Hospital Chief Stepping Down After a Year

docs.abstract: Dr Kenneth I Berns, chief executive of New York's Mount Sinai Medical Center, is resigning barely one year after assuming post; will remain on staff as professor; will be replaced by Dr Kenneth L Davis, who is currently dean of medical school; up to 500 health care workers will be laid off in hospitalwide shakeup; change is widely viewed as final refutation of 1998 merger with New York University Medical Center (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a fraud that went on for more than 15 years, complete with ''family meetings'' to create records to fool the auditors, who seem never to have caught on that something was amiss, even as a company that was barely breaking even was reporting more than $1 billion in nonexistent profits. That, in any case, is what the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission say went on at HealthSouth, the health care company run by Richard M. Scrushy, who is said to have directed the fraud. HealthSouth's former chief financial officer has agreed to enter a guilty plea and to cooperate with investigators.

headline.main: Market Place; In U.S. Eyes, a Notably Bold Case of Health Care Fraud

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris comment on HealthSouth Corp fraud case says case is unusual because public had virtually no idea of scope or magnitude of case before charges were filed March 19; holds case is also unusual in that it represents first charges filed under Sarbanes-Oxley law's requirement that top corporate executives certify financial statements; holds case echoes many earlier accounting fraud cases; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Guadalupe Castillo Ureña was widowed at 31, left alone with five children when her husband died trying to get to the United States from their hut here in the foothills of Mexico's southern Sierras. She was among the poorest of the poor -- scraping by, like half the people in Mexico, and half the world's six billion people, on $2 a day or less, barely surviving.

headline.main: With Little Loans, Mexican Women Overcome

docs.abstract: Article on Finca Mexico and 31 other small loan companies operating in Mexico, providing credit to hundreds of thousands of poor peasant women to run small businesses and acquire small bit of wealth; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation said today that it would sell, close or shrink 14 of its 114 hospitals and cut jobs and expenses to help cope with an expected decline in payments received from Medicare. Tenet, the nation's second-largest hospital chain behind HCA, is facing several federal investigations, one of them involving pricing policies that the company acknowledges led to unusually large payments from Medicare in certain cases. Under pressure, the company said it would change its practices, reducing its expected earnings for future years.

headline.main: Tenet to Sell or Shut Hospitals and Cut Jobs

docs.lead_paragraph: New York's trial lawyers have begun an advertising campaign to counter a growing political movement here and in Washington, led by doctors, insurance companies and Republican leaders, to reduce jury awards for pain and suffering. The New York State Trial Lawyers Association plans to begin running advertisements in major newspapers across the state on Tuesday, pointing out the important role civil suits have played in making products, workplaces and medical procedures safer.

headline.main: Trial Lawyers Begin Effort Against Cutting Jury Awards

docs.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE who are thinking about early retirement can benefit by examining the most recent copy of their employer's benefits statement to see what health coverage they will get and what it will cost. ''You may wind up saying to yourself, 'I better not retire before I'm eligible for Medicare,' '' said Joseph Martingale, a senior executive at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, an employee benefits consultancy.
docs.abstract: People who are thinking about early retirement should find out what their health coverage will cost, and some of them may discover that they would be better off working until they are eligible for Medicare (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: JIM LEUKER didn't want to retire, but three years ago he knew he had no choice. Mr. Leuker, a computer systems consultant who learned he was H.I.V. positive in 1987, was so worn down by his job and the viral assault on his body that quitting work seemed to be the only way to preserve his health -- and his life. His employer and his doctors endorsed his decision. Like many people, Mr. Leuker received disability insurance coverage through his employer. At first, the disability carrier approved his claim and began paying him $3,200 a month. But last spring, Mr. Leuker said, the insurer ordered him to undergo psychological testing; shortly afterward, the company cut off his payments despite medical records indicating he still suffered from extreme fatigue, headaches, sleep disorders and persistent diarrhea and nausea.
docs.abstract: Advocates for people with AIDS report that insurance companies are increasingly questioning AIDS-related disability claims now that drug therapies have extended patients' lives; say drugs have not improved patients' health enough to return to work and often have disabling side effects; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The large sign next to Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver telegraphed his message today even before he could fire his first shot at the governor for proposing a $1.2 billion reduction in state education spending next year: ''Education aid goes down, Property taxes go up.'' Just in case the point was lost on anyone, Mr. Silver warned that homeowners would face an average increase of 20 percent in their property tax bills, or about $400, if local schools were forced to raise money to offset the cuts proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki.

headline.main: Opponents Get Head Start In Fight for School Funds

docs.abstract: New York Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver calls on Gov George Pataki to restore state education funds; warns that property taxes will increase if local schools are forced to raise money to offset Pataki's proposed cuts; urges New Yorkers to voice their disapproval of Pataki plan; New York City Council Speaker Gifford Miller plans to coordinate citywide efforts against cuts (M)

byline.original: By WINNIE HU and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: In a rebuke to prosecutors, a federal judge dismissed the case yesterday against one of two men on trial in a health-insurance embezzlement scheme that prosecutors say cost Nassau County as much as $70 million. Judge Joanna Seybert said prosecutors had not offered enough evidence that Michael Agoglia, 53, the former chief financial officer of Benefit Plan Administrators, an insurance company, might be guilty of conspiracy and other charges. The charges, therefore, should not be considered by a jury, she ruled. Mr. Agoglia's lawyer, Robert S. Fink, described his client as ''relieved and happy.'' Mr. Agoglia's former boss, Albert E. Isernio, the former president of the company, is still on trial. Five other men, including a former top Nassau official, have pleaded guilty to corruption charges in the case. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Charges Dismissed In Insurance Case

docs.abstract: Federal Judge Joanna Seybert dismisses embezzlement charges against Michael Agoglia, former chief financial officer of Benefit Plan Administrators, saying prosecutors did not offer enough evidence; Agoglia's boss Albert Isernio is still on trial (S)
